text: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
label: BODY

text: FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF WEST VIRGINIA
label: BODY

text: AARON C. LEWIS,
label: BODY

text: Petitioner,
label: BODY

text: Civil Action No. 3:06-CV-47
label: BODY

text: Criminal Action No. 3:03-CR-17
label: BODY

text: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA,
label: BODY

text: (JUDGE BAILEY)
label: BODY

text: Respondent.
label: BODY

text: REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION
label: HH1

text: THAT § 2255 MOTION BE DENIED
label: BODY

text: I.  INTRODUCTION
label: HH2

text: On May 11, 2006, pro se petitioner filed a Motion under 28 U.S.C. § 2255 to Vacate, Set
label: BODY

text: Aside or Correct Sentence by a Person in Federal Custody.  The Government filed its response
label: BODY

text: II.  FACTS
label: HH2

text: Conviction and Sentence
label: HH3

text: Petitioner was named in a twelve count superseding indictment filed on June 3, 2003 in
label: BODY

text: the Northern District of West Virginia.  Petitioner was charged in count 1 in a conspiracy to
label: BODY

text: possess with the intent to distribute more than 50 grams of cocaine base in violation of 21 U.S.C.
label: BODY

text: § 846; in counts 2, 5, 7, 9, and 10 with distribution of six ounces of cocaine base in violation of
label: BODY

text: 21 U.S.C. § 841(a)(1); in counts 3, 4, 6, 8, and 11 with distribution of 1.85 grams of cocaine base
label: BODY

text: in violation of 21 U.S.C. § 841(a)(1); and in count 12 with aiding and abetting the distribution of
label: BODY

text: .37 grams of crack in violation of 18 U.S.C. § 2 and 21 U.S.C. § 841.
label: BODY

text: On August 13, 2003, petitioner was convicted by a jury on all twelve counts.  On
label: BODY

text: November 4, 2003, petitioner was sentenced to a term of imprisonment of 275 months on counts
label: BODY

text: 1, 2, 5, 7, 9, and 10 and 240 months, concurrent, on counts 3, 4, 6, 8, 11, and 12.
label: BODY

text: Appeal
label: HH3

text: On November 10, 2003, petitioner filed a notice of appeal. On July 6, 2004, the Fourth
label: BODY

text: Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed petitioner’s conviction and sentence.  Petitioner petitioned the
label: BODY

text: United States Supreme Court for a writ of certiorari. The Supreme Court denied petitioner’s
label: BODY

text: petition on February 22, 2005.
label: BODY

text: Federal Habeas Corpus
label: HH3

text: The petitioner asserts the following grounds for relief:
label: BODY

text: The Court did not have jurisdiction over the conspiracy alleged in Count 1
label: BODY

text: because petitioner was a juvenile during a portion of the conspiracy and the Court did not
label: BODY

text: comply with the requirements of the Federal Juvenile Delinquency Act, 18 U.S.C. § 5301, for
label: BODY

text: prosecuting a juvenile.
label: BODY

text: The Government’s failure to submit a Bill of Particulars detailing when, where,
label: BODY

text: and with whom the acts in Counts 2 through 7 occurred prejudiced petitioner because he was
label: BODY

text: unable to adequately prepare a defense for trial.
label: BODY

text: Newly discovered evidence, namely a Bill of Sale, establishes the government’s
label: BODY

text: witness, David Rosario, fabricated his statements about having bought cocaine from petitioner
label: BODY

text: on March 28, 2002.
label: BODY

text: The Government’s witnesses Joseph Lockett and Jonathan Crawford made
label: BODY

text: statements to the grand jury that were inconsistent with their prior statements made to
label: BODY

text: investigators.  Furthermore, there was insufficient evidence to convict petitioner of the
label: BODY

text: substantive drug charges in counts 2 through 11.
label: BODY

text: In its response to the Petitioner’s motion, the Government asserts:
label: BODY

text: The Court had jurisdiction over the acts alleged in Count 1 because although
label: BODY

text: petitioner joined the conspiracy as a juvenile, he continued his involvement as an adult.
label: BODY

text: Although the Government did not submit a Bill of Particulars, the superseding
label: BODY

text: indictment, witness lists, Jencks and Giglio materials provided to petitioner before trial
label: BODY

text: sufficiently apprised petitioner of the charges against him.
label: BODY

text: The Bill of Sale does not establish David Rosario fabricated his testimony.
label: BODY

text: Furthermore, petitioner failed to prove the five elements necessary for receiving a new trial
label: BODY

text: based on newly discovered evidence.
label: BODY

text: Petitioner failed to prove that no reasonable jury could have convicted him of the
label: BODY

text: substantive drug charges in counts 2 through 11.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation
label: HH3

text: Based upon a review of the record, the undersigned recommends that Petitioner’s § 2255
label: BODY

text: motion be denied and dismissed from the docket because his claims are without merit.
label: BODY

text: III.   ANALYSIS
label: HH2

text: “A petitioner collaterally attacking his sentence or conviction bears the burden of proving
label: BODY

text: his sentence or conviction was imposed in violation of the Constitution or laws of the United
label: BODY

text: States, that the court was without jurisdiction to impose such a sentence, that the sentence
label: BODY

text: exceeded the maximum authorized by law, or that the sentence otherwise is subject to collateral
label: BODY

text: attack.  28 U.S.C. § 2255. A motion collaterally attacking a petitioner’s sentence brought
label: BODY

text: pursuant to § 2255 requires the petitioner to establish his grounds by a preponderance of the
label: BODY

text: evidence.” Sutton v. United States of America, 2006 WL 36859, at *2 (E.D. Va. Jan. 4, 2006).
label: BODY

text: Timeliness of Motion
label: HH3

text: In 1996, the Anti-Terrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 [“AEDPA”] was
label: BODY

text: enacted, establishing a one-year limitation period within which to file any federal habeas corpus
label: BODY

text: motion.  28 U.S.C. §2255.  The limitation period shall run from the latest of:
label: BODY

text: 1) the date on which the judgment of conviction becomes final;
label: BODY

text: 2) the date on which the impediment to making the motion created by governmental
label: BODY

text: action in violation of the Constitution or laws of the United States is removed, if the movant was
label: BODY

text: prevented from making a motion by such governmental action;
label: BODY

text: 3) the date on which the right asserted was initially recognized by the Supreme Court, if
label: BODY

text: that right has been newly recognized by the Supreme Court and made retroactively applicable to
label: BODY

text: cases on collateral review; or
label: BODY

text: 4) the date on which the facts supporting the claim or claims presented could have been
label: BODY

text: discovered through the exercise of due diligence.
label: BODY

text: 28 U.S.C. § 2255.  Where a federal prisoner files a petition a writ of certiorari with the United
label: BODY

text: States Supreme Court, the judgment of conviction becomes final - thereby triggering the one-
label: BODY

text: year limitation - when the Supreme Court either denies certiorari or issues a decision on the
label: BODY

text: merits.  Clay v. United States, 537 U.S. 522, 525 (2003).
label: BODY

text: In the present case, the Supreme Court denied petitioner’s writ of certiorari on February
label: BODY

text: 22, 2005.  Petitioner therefore had until February 22, 2006 to file his motion under § 2255.  On
label: BODY

text: February 22, 2006, petitioner requested the Court grant him a two month extension to file his
label: BODY

text: motion under § 2255.  On March 13, 2006, the Court granted petitioner’s request and extended
label: BODY

text: the period within which petitioner may file his motion to May 12, 2006.  Petitioner filed his
label: BODY

text: motion on May 11, 2006.  Because petitioner filed his § 2255 motion within the period of time
label: BODY

text: designated by the Court, the Court finds petitioner’s motion was timely.
label: BODY

text: Procedurally Defaulted Issues
label: HH3

text: Before evaluating the merits of Petitioner’s claims, the Court must determine which of
label: BODY

text: Petitioner’s issues he may bring in his § 2255 motion.  It is well settled non-constitutional issues
label: BODY

text: that could have been raised on direct appeal but were not may not be raised in a collateral attack
label: BODY

text: such as a § 2255 motion.  Sunal v. Large, 332 U.S. 174, 178-79 (1947); Bousley v. United
label: BODY

text: States, 523 U.S. 614 (1998).  Constitutional issues that were capable of being raised on direct
label: BODY

text: appeal but were not may be raised in a § 2255 motion so long as the petitioner demonstrates 1)
label: BODY

text: “cause” that excuses his procedural default, and 2) “actual prejudice” resulting from the alleged
label: BODY

text: errors.  United States v. Maybeck, 23 F.3d 888, 891 (1994).  Petitioner may alternatively
label: BODY

text: demonstrate “actual innocence,” or that it is more likely than not, in light of all the evidence, that
label: BODY

text: no reasonable juror would have convicted him.”  Bousley v. United States, 523 U.S. 614, 621
label: BODY

text: (1998).  Finally, issues previously rejected on direct appeal may not be raised in a collateral
label: BODY

text: attack.  Boeckenhaupt v. United States, 537 F.2d 1182 (4th Cir. 1976).
label: BODY

text: The Court finds petitioner is not barred from raising his first issue because challenges to
label: BODY

text: the jurisdiction of the Court may be raised on collateral attack.  See 28 U.S.C. § 2255; see, also,
label: BODY

text: Sunal v. Large, 332 U.S. 174, 178-179 (1947).  However, petitioner is barred from raising issues
label: BODY

text: 2 and 3 because he has failed to show “cause” and “prejudice” for failing to raise them on direct
label: BODY

text: appeal.  Maybeck, 23 F.3d at 891.  Furthermore, petitioner is barred from raising issue 4 because
label: BODY

text: challenges to the sufficiency of the evidence may not be raised on collateral attack and because
label: BODY

text: 1 Petitioner raised the following four issues on direct appeal: 1) Whether the United
label: BODY

text: States presented sufficient evidence to support defendant’s conviction on the substantive drug
label: BODY

text: distribution charges; 2) whether the district court committed clear error in its calculation of
label: BODY

text: defendant’s relevant conduct; 3) whether the district court plainly erred in its instructions to the
label: BODY

text: jury as to the object of the conspiracy; 4) whether the district court plainly erred in its
label: BODY

text: instructions to the jury concerning defendant’s Pinkerton (Pinkerton v. United States, 328 U.S.
label: BODY

text: 640 (1946)) liability regarding charged conspiracy.
label: BODY

text: 2   The “act” alleged in Count 1 is the “criminal agreement” itself, not any of the actual
label: BODY

text: distributions of cocaine that were the object of the criminal conspiracy. United States v.
label: BODY

text: Shambani, 513 U.S. 10, 16 (1994).  As held by the Supreme Court, the government, in order to
label: BODY

text: prove a violation of 21 U.S.C. § 846, “need not prove the commission of any overt acts in
label: BODY

text: furtherance of the conspiracy. . . . [T]he criminal agreement itself is the actus reas.”  Id.
label: BODY

text: petitioner’s previous challenge, made on direct appeal, to the sufficiency of the evidence as to
label: BODY

text: counts 2, 5, 7, 9, and 10 was rejected.  Boeckenhaupt, 537 F.2d at 1182.1
label: BODY

text: Issue 1 - Whether the Court Had Jurisdiction Over Count 1
label: HH3

text: Petitioner alleges the Court did not have jurisdiction over the conspiracy charged in
label: BODY

text: Count 1 because petitioner was a juvenile through a period of the conspiracy and the Court failed
label: BODY

text: to comply with the requirements of the Federal Juvenile Delinquency Act, 18 U.S.C. § 5031 et
label: BODY

text: seq for prosecuting a juvenile.  The Government contends the Court had jurisdiction over Count
label: BODY

text: 1 because although petitioner was a juvenile at the time he joined the conspiracy, he remained in
label: BODY

text: the conspiracy as an adult.
label: BODY

text: The Court finds the trial Court had jurisdiction over the acts alleged in Count 1.2  Count 1
label: BODY

text: of the superseding indictment charged petitioner in a conspiracy alleged to have occurred “from
label: BODY

text: on or about January, 1999 to on or about the date of the return of the indictment,” or June 3,
label: BODY

text: 2003.   Because petitioner was born on January 7, 1984, acts committed by petitioner prior to
label: BODY

text: January 7, 2002 were committed as a juvenile and acts committed by petitioner on or after
label: BODY

text: January 7, 2002 were committed as an adult.  Petitioner therefore allegedly joined the conspiracy
label: BODY

text: as a juvenile.  However, because the Government proved petitioner’s involvement in the
label: BODY

text: conspiracy continued into his adulthood, the Court had jurisdiction and his conviction may be
label: BODY

text: sustained.  United States v. Spoone, 741 F.2d 680 (4th Cir. 1984) [upholding conspiracy
label: BODY

text: conviction of adult defendant who joined conspiracy as a juvenile yet committed one overt act in
label: BODY

text: furtherance of the conspiracy as an adult].  The fact the Government presented evidence of
label: BODY

text: petitioner’s involvement as a juvenile does not disturb the Court’s finding because the Court
label: BODY

text: finds the jury was properly instructed they were to consider evidence of petitioner’s juvenile
label: BODY

text: involvement merely for purposes outlined in the F.R.E. § 404(b) (such as knowledge, intent, and
label: BODY

text: motive), not as evidence of his guilt of the crime.  Id. at 687; see F.R.E. 404(b).  Finally, the
label: BODY

text: Court finds petitioner’s reliance on the Federal Juvenile Delinquency Act is misplaced.  The Act
label: BODY

text: applies to the prosecution of a juvenile in federal court.  18 U.S.C. §§ 5031, 5032.  The Act does
label: BODY

text: not apply to the prosecution of an adult in federal court who joined a conspiracy as a juvenile.
label: BODY

text: Spoone, 741 F.2d at 687.
label: BODY

text: Issue 2  - Whether Petitioner was Prejudiced By the Government’s Failure to
label: HH3

text: Submit a Bill of Particulars
label: BODY

text: Petitioner argues the Government’s failure to submit a Bill of Particulars as to Counts 2
label: BODY

text: through 7 of the indictment prejudiced his ability to prepare a defense for trial.  The Government
label: BODY

text: contends although the Government did not comply with the Court’s order to submit a Bill of
label: BODY

text: Particulars, petitioner was not prejudiced by the Government’s noncompliance because
label: BODY

text: petitioner received the requested information in the superseding indictment, witness lists, and
label: BODY

text: Jencks and Giglio material.
label: BODY

text: The original indictment filed April 2, 2003 charged petitioner in Counts 2 through 7 with
label: BODY

text: distributing cocaine base, “in or about January, February and March of 2002,” in violation of 21
label: BODY

text: 3 Docket No. 1.
label: BODY

text: 4 Docket No. 15.
label: BODY

text: 5 Docket No. 19.
label: BODY

text: 6 The superseding indictment also added four additional charges, Counts 9, 10, 11, and
label: BODY

text: U.S.C. § 841(a)(1).3  On April 30, 2003, petitioner moved the Court to order the Government to
label: BODY

text: submit a Bill of Particulars detailing a) the identity of others involved in each count, b) the
label: BODY

text: alleged circumstances of petitioner’s participation in each count, c) which acts were purportedly
label: BODY

text: committed by petitioner while he was under eighteen, d) what acts in support of the conspiracy
label: BODY

text: were purportedly committed by petitioner after he was eighteen, e) additional detail on the time
label: BODY

text: and location of the acts charged in Counts 2 through 7.4   On May 14, 2003, the Court granted
label: BODY

text: petitioner’s motion, ordering the Government to submit a Bill of Particulars stating when, where,
label: BODY

text: and with whom the acts in Counts 1 through 7 took place and which, if any, of the alleged acts
label: BODY

text: were committed prior to petitioner’s eighteenth birthday.5  The Government objected to the
label: BODY

text: Order but the Court’s Order was affirmed.
label: BODY

text: On June 3, 2003, the Government filed a superseding indictment that specified in greater
label: BODY

text: detail the dates of the alleged acts in Counts 2 through 7.6  The new dates established the alleged
label: BODY

text: acts were committed by petitioner after he turned eighteen.  The superseding indictment did not,
label: BODY

text: however, provide any detail as to where or with whom the acts in Counts 2 through 7 took place.
label: BODY

text: On May 27, 2003, the Government provided petitioner with a witness list and Jencks and Giglio
label: BODY

text: material.  The Government never submitted a Bill of Particulars.
label: BODY

text: The Court finds petitioner was not prejudiced by the Government’s failure to submit the
label: BODY

text: Bill of Particulars because the superseding indictment, witnesses lists, and Jencks and Giglio
label: BODY

text: materials provided the information originally sought in the Bill of Particulars and sufficiently
label: BODY

text: enabled petitioner to prepare a defense, minimize surprise at trial, and avoid double jeopardy.
label: BODY

text: United States v. Fletcher, 74 F.3d 49, 53 (4th Cir. 1996); United States v. Shembari, 484 F.2d
label: BODY

text: 931, 934-35 (4th Cir. 1973).  Specifically, the dates contained in the superseding indictment
label: BODY

text: sufficiently apprised petitioner of “when” the acts in Counts 2 through 7 occurred, that all acts in
label: BODY

text: Counts 2 through 7 occurred after petitioner turned eighteen, and “where” each alleged act
label: BODY

text: occurred.  Similarly, the witness lists sufficiently apprised petitioner of the individuals “with
label: BODY

text: whom” the acts in Counts 2 through 7 took place and were given to petitioner in sufficient time
label: BODY

text: before trial.  The Court finds the failure of the witness lists to specify which witness would
label: BODY

text: testify to which of the alleged acts is insignificant, because the government need not provide
label: BODY

text: “detailed disclosure of the government’s evidence in advance of trial.”  United States v.
label: BODY

text: Automated Medical Labs, Inc., 770 F.2d 399, 405 (4th Cir. 1985).  Petitioner was permitted to
label: BODY

text: contact the witnesses to determine the specifics of their testimony.
label: BODY

text: Issue 3 - Whether the Government’s Witness Fabricated Evidence Before the Grand
label: HH3

text: Jury.
label: BODY

text: Petitioner alleges newly discovered evidence establishes David Rosario, a witness for the
label: BODY

text: Government, fabricated statements to Detective Snyder.  The Government argues the “newly
label: BODY

text: discovered” evidence fails to establish Mr. Rosario fabricated testimony.  Additionally, the
label: BODY

text: Government alleges even if the evidence establishes Mr. Rosario fabricated testimony, the
label: BODY

text: evidence fails to establish grounds for vacating petitioner’s conviction.
label: BODY

text: On June 3, 2003, Detective Snyder testified before the grand jury about statements made
label: BODY

text: to him by David Rosario.  The statements, which established the basis for Count 12, concerned a
label: BODY

text: controlled buy made by an undercover agent from Mr. Rosario.  Detective Snyder testified to the
label: BODY

text: grand jury Mr. Rosario told him he obtained the drugs at issue from a black male in a green
label: BODY

text: SUV.  Detective Snyder also testified Mr. Rosario, after pleading guilty and getting debriefed,
label: BODY

text: said he obtained the drugs at issue from petitioner on March 28, 2002.  Petitioner concedes that
label: BODY

text: he owned a green color SUV but argues he did not purchase a green color SUV until April 6,
label: BODY

text: 2003.  Petitioner has submitted a Bill of Sale as proof of his purchase and proof Mr. Rosario
label: BODY

text: fabricated his statements to Detective Snyder.
label: BODY

text: The Court finds petitioner’s argument is without merit.  First, the Bill of Sale establishes
label: BODY

text: petitioner bought a green-color SUV on April 6, 2002, not April 6, 2003 as alleged by petitioner.
label: BODY

text: Second, the Bill of Sale does not definitively establish Mr. Rosario fabricated his testimony.
label: BODY

text: The proximity in time between March 28, 2002 (the date Mr. Rosario alleged he encountered
label: BODY

text: petitioner in the green SUV)  and April 6, 2002 (the date petitioner bought his car) makes it
label: BODY

text: entirely possible Mr. Rosario was merely mistaken as to the exact date of the transaction as
label: BODY

text: opposed to intentionally fabricating evidence.  Second, even if the Bill of Sale could be
label: BODY

text: construed as proving Mr. Rosario fabricated his testimony, petitioner has failed to establish the
label: BODY

text: required grounds for a new trial.  Pursuant to Rule 33 of the Federal Rules of Criminal
label: BODY

text: Procedure, a motion for a new trial based on newly discovered evidence may be granted if the
label: BODY

text: petitioner proves all the following five factors:
label: BODY

text: “a) the evidence must be, in fact, newly discovered, i.e., discovered since the trial; b) the
label: BODY

text: facts must be alleged from which the court may infer diligence on the part of the movant;
label: BODY

text: c) the evidence relied on must not be merely cumulative or impeaching; d) it must be
label: BODY

text: material to the issues involved; and e) it must be such, and of such nature, that on a new
label: BODY

text: trial, the newly discovered evidence would probably produce an aquittal.”
label: BODY

text: United States v. Custis, 988 F.2d 1355, 1359 (4th Cir. 1993) (quoting United States v. Bales, 813
label: BODY

text: F.2d 1289, 1295 (4th Cir. 1987); see, also, United States v. Singh, 54 F.3d 1182, 1190 (4th Cir.
label: BODY

text: 1995).  Petitioner has failed to prove the above elements.  First, petitioner has failed to prove the
label: BODY

text: 7 Joseph Lockett testified he bought cocaine from petitioner in January, February, and
label: BODY

text: into March.
label: BODY

text: 8 William Pennington testified at the trial he was in the Eastern Regional jail with Mr.
label: BODY

text: Rosario and that Mr. Rosario told him he hated petitioner and intended to falsely testify against
label: BODY

text: petitioner at trial.
label: BODY

text: Bill of Sale was discovered only since the trial nor that he exercised diligence in attempting to
label: BODY

text: locate the Bill of Sale.  Presumably, petitioner was aware prior to the start of the August 11,
label: BODY

text: 2003 trial that he had purchased a green-color SUV on or about April 2002 and that a Bill of
label: BODY

text: Sale likely existed to prove the date of his purchase.  Second, petitioner has failed to show the
label: BODY

text: Bill of Sale would “probably produce an acquittal.”   The Bill of Sale would merely have
label: BODY

text: impeached Mr. Rosario’s ability to accurately recall dates rather than produce an acquittal due to
label: BODY

text: the detail of Mr. Rosario’s testimony coupled with Joseph Lockett’s testimony petitioner
label: BODY

text: distributed cocaine base in March 2002.7  Although William Pennington testified Mr. Rosario
label: BODY

text: intended to falsely testify against petitioner, 8 William Pennington’s testimony was
label: BODY

text: uncorroborated.
label: BODY

text: Issue 4 - Whether There was Sufficient Evidence to Convict Petitioner of Counts 2
label: HH3

text: Through 11.
label: BODY

text: Petitioner alleges witnesses Joseph Lockett’s and Jonathan Crawford’s statements to the
label: BODY

text: grand jury were inconsistent with their statements to investigators and that Lockett’s testimony
label: BODY

text: was “unsubstantiated and uncorroborated” such that it was “unreasonable for the jury to base
label: BODY

text: convictions on such evidence.”  Petitioner thus broadly alleges there was insufficient evidence to
label: BODY

text: support his convictions of counts 2 through 11.  The Government contends petitioner has failed
label: BODY

text: to show the evidence was insufficient.
label: BODY

text: Generally, a jury’s conviction may be reversed for insufficient evidence where, “viewing
label: BODY

text: the evidence in the light most favourable to the government, any rational trier of fact would have
label: BODY

text: 9 Lockett admitted on cross-examination he had not originally told investigators about the
label: BODY

text: six ounce quantities and that he had testified to the grand jury his purchases from petition began
label: BODY

text: in the Fall of 2002.
label: BODY

text: found the defendant guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.”  United States v. Reavis, 48 F.3d 763,
label: BODY

text: 771 (4th Cir. 1995).   Because it is the jury’s view of the sufficiency of the evidence which
label: BODY

text: controls, “[t]he relevant question is not whether the appellate court is [itself] convinced beyond a
label: BODY

text: reasonable doubt.”  Id.; Burks v. Unites States, 437 U.S. 1, 17 (1978).  Similarly, it is the jury’s
label: BODY

text: province, not the appellate court’s, to evaluate and determine a witness’ credibility.  Johnson v
label: BODY

text: United States, 271 F.2d 596, 597 (4th Cir. 1959) [holding, “it is the duty of the trier of fact to
label: BODY

text: hear the evidence, to determine the credibility of the witnesses and to determine the weight to be
label: BODY

text: accorded to the testimony of each witness”].
label: BODY

text: The Court finds petitioner has failed to meet his burden of showing that no rational jury
label: BODY

text: could have found him guilty beyond a reasonable doubt of counts 2 through 11.  Reavis, 48 F.3d
label: BODY

text: at 771.  Regarding Counts 2, 5, 7, 9, and 10, witness Lockett testified he purchased six ounces of
label: BODY

text: cocaine from petitioner on five occasions, beginning around the time of the Superbowl in 2002,
label: BODY

text: two weeks following the Superbowl, near Valentine’s Day, and the first and third weeks in
label: BODY

text: March 2002.  Petitioner argues Lockett’s prior statements to the grand jury that petitioner sold
label: BODY

text: him 28 grams on each occasion, rather than six ounces, impeached  his testimony and left his
label: BODY

text: testimony “uncorroborated and unsubstantiated.”  In viewing the evidence in the light most
label: BODY

text: favourable to the government, the Court finds there was sufficient evidence for a jury to
label: BODY

text: convicted petitioner of counts 2, 5, 7, 9, and 10.  Furthermore, the Court notes the jury was made
label: BODY

text: aware of Lockett’s inconsistent statements to the grand jury and investigators9 and nevertheless
label: BODY

text: decided to believe Lockett’s testimony, as evidenced by their conviction on counts 2, 5, 7, 9, and
label: BODY

text: 10.  The Court will not disturb the jury’s assessment of a witness’ credibility.   Johnson, 271
label: BODY

text: F.2d at 597.
label: BODY

text: Similarly, the Court finds petitioner has failed to prove that no rational jury could find
label: BODY

text: him guilty beyond a reasonable doubt of counts 3, 4, 6, 8, and 11.  Witness Crawford testified
label: BODY

text: before the jury that he purchased “wholesale” amounts of cocaine base from petitioner five to ten
label: BODY

text: times in early 2002, in or around January, February and March.  Petitioner argues Crawford’s
label: BODY

text: testimony was inconsistent with statements he made to the grand jury that the purchases
label: BODY

text: occurred in 2000 and 2001.  The Court, again, finds, petitioner has failed to meet his burden of
label: BODY

text: proving his convicted rested on insufficient evidence.  In addition to there being sufficient
label: BODY

text: evidence to support his conviction for counts 3, 4, 6, 8, and 11, including Crawford’s testimony
label: BODY

text: and other witness’ testimony establishing petitioner’s involvement in the sale of drugs on or
label: BODY

text: about January, February, and March 2002, the jury determined Crawford’s testimony was
label: BODY

text: credible.  The Court will not disturb its finding.  Johnson, 271 F.2d at 597.
label: BODY

text: V.   Recommendation
label: HH2

text: For the foregoing reasons, the undersigned recommends that Petitioner’s § 2255 motion
label: BODY

text: be denied and dismissed from the docket because petitioner’s claims are without merit.
